Suggestion: The issuer authenticates the document, but the data *in* the document might be fraudulent at the source (e.g. corrupt inspector, dry-labbing, lying exporter). Verification proves the *Issuer* said it, not that it is *True* in the physical world.

Applicable Case Studies: commercial-invoices-customs.md, commercial-insurance-policy-documents.md, condo-townhouse-disclosures.md, consent-records.md, cruise-final-folios.md, contracts-agreements-multipage.md, data-sharing-agreements.md, film-completion-bonds.md, equity-crowdfunding-certificates.md
Suggestion: Verifying the *document* is real isn't enough; you need to verify specific *data fields* (e.g. 'Does it cover Cyber Liability?'). A hash of the whole PDF works, but if the user wants to check *just* one value without seeing the rest, we need granular hashing (Merkle trees) or selective disclosure.

Verification is a snapshot in time. Stakeholders need push notifications for state changes (e.g. License Suspended, Deposit Released) rather than re-verifying manually. Requires a subscription/webhook model.

The security model relies on the *public* (neighbors, diners) to perform the verification. If the public is apathetic or doesn't know how to scan, the fraud succeeds. Depends on high-visibility signage and public education.

The sheer volume of physical credential production (e.g. 500 badges in 24 hours for an event) creates a logistical bottleneck that can undermine the system if issuers revert to 'easy' unverified paper to save time.
